'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'user_view_type': 'public', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2024-09-26T07:48:35Z', 'updated_at': '2024-09-26T07:48:35Z', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'body': "> @lhotari @poorbarcode Thanks for bring up the customer's priority discussion. I think the Key_Shared subscription missed the consumer's priority support before. The expected behavior for consumer's priority is if you have a higher priority consumer under the subscription, the consumer with lower priority should not receive message until the consumer with higher priority get disconnected. I would like to suggest to take this one out of this PR. This issue is not easy to resolve in the Consumer Selector since different key will select different consumers unless we remove all the low priority consumers out of the Consumer Selector.\r\n\r\n@codelipenghui  Valid point. I have removed the priority handling. We can come back to that after PIP-379 has been implemented since it's easy to solve there. The current PIP-379 implementation will also handle cases where hash ranges switch from one existing consumer to another existing consumer. That will be essential in addressing the priority handling. It's also possible to later add the logic that you are describing to the model that is in this PR.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/apache/pulsar/issues/comments/2376181672/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}, {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/apache/pulsar/issues/comments/2376288786', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/23327#issuecomment-2376288786', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/apache/pulsar/issues/23327', 'id': 2376288786, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOA7PXtM6No0oS', 'user': {'login': 'lhotari', 'id': 66864, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjY2ODY0', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/66864?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/lhotari', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lhotari/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'user_view_type': 'public', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2024-09-26T08:27:39Z', 'updated_at': '2024-09-26T08:41:52Z', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'body': '> I\'m thinking another simple solution to replace the `NavigableMap<Integer, List<Consumer>> hashRing;` to `NavigableMap<Integer, HashRangeAutoSplitStickyKeyConsumerSelector> hashRing;`. Since the `HashRangeAutoSplitStickyKeyConsumerSelector` used a fixed hash range and it can also distribute loads to multiple consumers. ConsistentHashingStickyKeyConsumerSelector + HashRangeAutoSplitStickyKeyConsumerSelector together will resolve the both load balance and hash collision issue.\r\n\r\n@codelipenghui I was also thinking about that type of solution; however, it won\'t be effective. The reason for this is that each hash range in the actual hash ring is not evenly sized. Even if the embedded hash ring would perfectly distribute the duplicate consumers, it wouldn\'t solve the overall distibution.\r\nThat\'s also why the previous solution in this PR didn\'t work properly, even though the consumers were evenly assigned across all hash ranges when there were collisions. That\'s why any embedded hash ring or container solution work and I have reverted those changes from this PR and taken a different approach.\r\n\r\nThis would be a simple problem to solve with an additional key. I guess @poorbarcoded suggested using a client IP address or port. The client address would be a useful additional key, but in many k8s environments, the IP address is masked when the ingress solution doesn\'t sustain the original IP address. The IP address of a proxy isn\'t very useful.\r\n\r\nI have refactored the approach in this PR to use a hash-based solution where the idea is that the additional key for the hash would be the arrival index of the consumer for a particular name. If a consumer leaves and reconnects immediately, it would retain the same ranges. If consumers leave and reconnect in different order, the result wouldn\'t be consistent from a single consumer\'s viewpoint. The consumer would have to have an unique name in that case.\r\nIn the current version there\'s no consistency for this type of case at all. `consumerList.get(hash % consumerList.size())` depends on the number of connected consumers and that will vary. It\'s not a "breaking change" to have a way to mitigate the duplicate consumer name behavior, even when there isn\'t full consistency between different phases.\r\n\r\nThe distribution is properly even now with the changes (I added a test case for proving that). There\'s also a test case that validates that with duplicate consumer names, there is some level of consistency for limited use cases (when a consumer leaves and then rejoins).', 'reactions': {'url':
